Este juego lo tenÃ­a desde hace tiempo y no habÃ­a tenido oportunidad de jugarlo, sabÃ­a que era un juego bastante bueno pero nunca me informÃ© nada de Ã©l, a simple vista es un juego de puzzles con portales y ya pero durante el juego te vas dando cuenta de que no, durante la primera mitad del juego (la primera hora o la primera hora y media) van habiendo comentarios que te quedas medio desubicado pero todo lo demÃ¡s es bastante soft, despuÃ©s de la segunda mitad es cuando le empiezas a dar sentido a todo y todo empieza a darle ese tono oscuro o un poco mÃ¡s diferente de lo que habÃ­a sido al juego.
La parte final es la mejor parte del juego, bastante divertida y con bastante tensiÃ³n, los puzzles no son tan difÃ­ciles pero te podrÃ­as estancar en alguno.
Recomendado 100% para usuarios que les gustaron juegos como "We Were Here" o juegos de puzzles algo parecidos, Â¡bastante diferente la historia a lo que me esperaba!

Right off the bat this game is really small, if you play nonstop all day you'll for sure finish it. That being said, it's super fun. I get stumped really easily on puzzle games and this was challenging in the best ways. Some things might take a few times to achieve/fully complete but nothing was so impossible for me that I felt like I couldn't finish them. Good game.

ê°“ê²œ ã„¹ã…‡

The "Test Chambers" commentary and credit roll are superb. In case you're rubbing your eyes, I indeed said the credits are off the chain. With all this talk of cake and missiles, I feel like a certain someone might have been in the idea room. If you know, you know.

Portal hopping and combat both come in linear and non-linear forms, but both are fun. Aside from the grand finale (I won't go into details), the combat really comes second to the portals. Not only is it a trip to see yourself entering a portal from the view of the portal you're about to exit from, the stability of jumping between parts of the room is just oh so marvelous.

Sound design is good. Nothing extraordinary, but satisfactory.

I only finally got a chance to play this game after years of hearing about it, and it really lives up to the hype. The plotline gets more and more interesting as it goes, the puzzles are engaging and challenging, and the song at the end is great. If this hasn't already been recommended to you a dozen times, here I am, recommending it again.

At the time of Portal's release, Valve was known for innovative gameplay that forced you to think outside the box by utilizing the objects around you rather than just shooting enemies to proceed. Portal pushes that formula to an extreme, removing the enemies entirely in favor of physics and momentum based puzzles. It serves as soft-prequel to the Half-Life series taking place in the facility of Black Mesa's biggest competitor, Aperture Science. Where Black Mesa failed at their teleportation experiments, Aperture seems to have perfected it, localizing their portal tech to the size of a handheld gun. The portal gun is an absolute blast to play with, and Valve seems to know this since they built a game centered around the mechanic. Though short, the campaign is tight from start to finish. There's some well written humor here and you'll love the antagonist, GlaDOS. It's an instant classic and exemplifies Valve when they were at their peak.
